title: How to Get Green out of Blonde Hair

steps.title: Wash your hair.
steps.content: Wash your hair. This should help the green color come out, or at least fade a bit. Your hair should be clean before you continue to the next steps.

steps.title: Make the vinegar mixture.
steps.content: Make the vinegar mixture. Mix 1/2 cup of water with 1/4 cup of vinegar in a bowl that is big enough to hold all the hair that has turned green, which is usually only the tips.

steps.title: Soak your hair.
steps.content: Soak your hair. In the bowl filled with the vinegar mixture, soak your hair for about two minutes.

steps.title: Add baking soda.
steps.content: Add baking soda. Add 2–3 tablespoons (29.6–44.4 ml) of baking soda to the water while your hair is still in the bowl. Let it fizz up and get in your hair for 2-3 minutes. You can also make a paste out of shampoo and baking soda and use this to wash your hair in the shower.

steps.title: Dry your hair.
steps.content: Dry your hair. Take your hair out and lay it on a dry towel. Pat it dry until it isn't dripping.

steps.title: Rinse your hair.
steps.content: Rinse your hair. Rinse your hair in warm water until all the vinegar is gone. To make sure all the vinegar is out, put a small lock of hair in your mouth and suck on it. If you taste vinegar, rinse it more thoroughly.

steps.title: Add hydrogen peroxide.
steps.content: Add hydrogen peroxide. If your hair is still green at this point (your hair should still be damp), put 4-5 teaspoons of hydrogen peroxide in your hand and comb it through with your fingers. You can also rub the hydrogen peroxide into your strands with your hands. Do not apply it to your scalp. Let the peroxide stay in your hair until the green is out. Watch your hair to see when the green is gone and then rinse.

steps.title: Check out the results.
steps.content: Check out the results. If your hair is still green after using hydrogen peroxide, then you may just have to let it wear out.

steps.title: Wash your hair with shampoo.
steps.content: Wash your hair with shampoo. This will help lessen the green to begin with, but it is also important to proceed with clean hair.

steps.title: Wash your hair with tomato juice.
steps.content: Wash your hair with tomato juice. Take a cup of tomato juice (or tomato soup) and pour it on your head. Run your fingers through your hair to make sure the tomato juice covers your hair evenly. Let it sit for 2-3 minutes. Alternatively, you can use ketchup instead of tomato juice or tomato soup. Ketchup is less runny and can be much more manageable in the cleanup process. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse your hair.
steps.content: Rinse your hair. Rinse the tomato juice completely out of your hair. You can repeat washing with tomato juice and rinsing a second time if you want to be extra thorough.

steps.title: Let your hair dry.
steps.content: Let your hair dry. Allow your hair to dry completely. You can sleep on it overnight or just wait several hours. Note: Do not blow dry your hair. Make sure you let it dry naturally.

steps.title: Purchase some professional shampoo.
steps.content: Purchase some professional shampoo. There are several types of commercial hair care products intended for swimmers that can help remove the green from hair when natural home remedies just won't cut it. Try Malibu C Swimmers shampoo and conditioner Sally Beauty's Ion Swimmer's shampoo. [2] X Research source The main ingredients to look for in the shampoo you choose are aloe, Vitamin E, and EDTA (Edetic Acid). [3] X Research source These will help condition and strengthen your hair and fight the discoloration.

steps.title: Wash your hair with the professional clarifying shampoo.
steps.content: Wash your hair with the professional clarifying shampoo. Follow the instructions on the bottle. [4] X Research source Alternatively, you can use a leave-in pre-swim treatment for preventative measures. Try Malibu C Swimmer's Natural Wellness Treatment or H2O Pre Swim Gel. These treatments restore color, seal the hair, and help prevent future discoloration.

steps.title: Rinse your hair.
steps.content: Rinse your hair. Rinse the special shampoo out of your hair completely.

steps.title: Let your hair dry.
steps.content: Let your hair dry. Don't blow dry your hair; just let it dry naturally. Alternatively, you can get a salon treatment called a seal coat (or a gloss coat ) that prevents the copper in the water from attaching to the cuticles in your hair. This works best on shorter hair.

steps.title: Wet your hair.
steps.content: Wet your hair. Dry hair absorbs moisture and whatever else is accompanying that moisture. Having wet hair will provide protection because your hair will already be saturated with water, so it will not absorb whatever is in the pool. Take a moment to wet your hair using water from a shower or sink before you go swimming. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Condition your hair before you go swimming.
steps.content: Condition your hair before you go swimming. Conditioner provides a barrier between your hair and the chlorine in the pool, so it can help to prevent your hair from turning green. Before you hop into the pool, apply a layer of conditioner to protect it. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Wear a swim cap.
steps.content: Wear a swim cap. A swim cap will cover your hair completely and prevent it from coming into contact with the chlorine in the water. Try putting on a swim cap to prevent green hair from the pool water.
